Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: RUI: Multi-dimensional Recommendation in Complex Heterogeneous Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Personalized information access via recommendation is a mainstay of today's online information systems. As online information sources become larger, more varied and more complex, new recommendation tools are needed that can integrate all of the dimensions of the data when making personalized recommendations. This project will develop new recommendation techniques appropriate to the scale and complexity of online social networks. In particular, it will study how different decompositions of a network can be used create multiple recommendation components, and how these components can be combined into a single weighted ensemble. The project will enable more effective and efficient generation of personalized recommendations, helping users find useful connections even in large and complex information networks.

This project will explore a recommendation approach known as the Weighted Hybrid of Low-Dimensionality Recommenders (WHyLDR), which has proved effective in recommendation for the social web. WHyLDR decomposes heterogeneous networks into collections of two-dimensional matrices on the basis of meta-path expansions, where a meta-path represents a composition of link relations over the network. The low-dimensional components are combined using learned weights. One challenge of this research is that the number of meta-paths is unbounded. Therefore, the project will explore analytic criteria by which to evaluate the relative value of components in a hybrid. The project will experiment with four complex heterogeneous network data sets drawn from very different areas: employment, travel, music and scientific bibliography, using a variety of recommendation tasks and evaluation metrics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When a user listens to a music track, consults a scientific article, or reads a restaurant review, they are not just interacting with a single piece of information. They are interacting with a web of information in which, for example, music tracks are associated with artists, labels, and genres; articles are associated with authors, venues, and fields of inquiry, etc. These associations form large complex, heterogeneous networks. If we are to generate recommendations -- personalized suggestions -- with these networks, it makes sense to use as much of the network as possible.

The aim of this research project was to explore the effective integration of complex heterogeneous network data into the generation of recommendations through the use of meta-paths, specific typed paths that create both proximal and distal relations in the network. For example, in a network of scientific publications, a meta-path might relate author A to all of the venues where a paper appeared that was cited by some paper written by one of A's co-authors: a co-author / paper / citation / venue meta-path. Each such relation gives rise to a separate recommendation component and these components can be combined into a hybrid recommender system. Our work demonstrated that longer network paths sometimes were more effective sources of information than shorter paths. However, the multiplicity of longer paths requires an effective means to controlling which paths are used. We showed that a measure based on information gain could be used to prune path generation and to serve as a heuristic for weighting recommendation components. We also showed that the relations created by extended meta-paths could be used as input to multi-relational matrix factorization.

In experiments conducted on a number of real-world recommendation data sets, our multi-relational model was found to outperform a variety of state-of-the-art baselines. We also showed that the compute-intensive process of generating meta-path expansions could be made more efficient by approximating depth-first expansion with random walks without sacrificing recommendation accuracy.

The project supported the education of two PhD student researchers including a female student from a population underrepresented in computer science. It also contributed concepts, techniques, and data that were shared with graduate and undergraduate students in courses taught by the PI in social network analysis and recommender systems. Findings from the work were published in the journal ACM Transactions on the Web as well as at the ACM Conference on Recommender Systems and the ACM Conference on User Modeling, Adaptation, and Personalization, and others.
